feed.title: Combined summary - Going to tag 0.9.2 final

entry.title: Combined summary - Going to tag 0.9.2 final
entry.summary: Bitcoin developers discussed the potential risks of last-minute changes to language imports in June 2014. The concern was that someone could maliciously change strings at the last minute in a language maintainers don't know well, which could pose a small holistic risk to the project. Jeff Garzik suggested implementing translation freeze points to address this issue. Wladimir stated that translations follow a different cycle than the rest of the code and are entered and reviewed through Transifex.In a conversation dated June 14, 2014, Un Ix joked about the translation process, and Wladimir responded that there is post-processing done on the script to remove stray control characters, but there is no check for number and presence of formatting characters. Matt Whitlock explained that it is more of an issue of accidental breakage than any maliciousness when testing the translation process in software development. A single character in the wrong place in a language bundle can cause runtime failure leading to issues like scrapping the whole release which could prompt users to question the quality control process of the dev team. The failure is defined as extra text that pushes a UI element down, making the button the user needs to click no longer visible. This kind of failure cannot be tested except by having a human being run through some example workflows, which presumably happens during the release process. In an email exchange, Pavel Janík suggested that new data could break the user interface, but it is unclear what system or user interface they were referring to.The developers emphasized the importance of avoiding any unnecessary changes to such a complex system. They also discussed the possibility of someone maliciously changing strings at the last minute in a language maintainers don't know well, which could pose a small holistic risk to the project. It is important to note the emphasis on maintaining quality control and ensuring that even small changes can cause severe problems.In another email exchange between Un Ix and Wladimir, Un Ix joked about offering a prize for anyone who could find malicious strings within the next hour. However, Wladimir cautioned against focusing on such a task and instead suggested looking out for icebergs over wrongly arranged deck chairs. Wladimir, a developer working on Bitcoin Core version 0.9.2rc1 and 0.9.2rc2, stated that there have been no new issues with either version. As a result, he plans to tag 0.9.2 final soon. He asked users to report any critical issues they haven't reported yet, so he can address them before the release. If no issues are reported, Wladimir will do a last-minute language import and tag the release at the end of the (UTC) day so that gitian builds can be started.On the Bitcoin-development mailing list, there was a discussion regarding translation updates. Jeff Garzik suggested that there should be a translation freeze point to prevent any malicious changes made at the last minute in a language where maintainers may not be familiar with all the strings. Wladimir responded by saying that translations follow a very different cycle than the rest of the code and that entering and reviewing them happens inside Transifex. He also mentioned that someone could maliciously change strings but it is a small risk. Despite this, he decided not to do the translation update if it would make everyone happy.In a conversation between Wladimir and Pavel Janík, Wladimir mentioned about doing a last-minute language import if he does not hear anything. However, Pavel warned him that this import could actually break things and advised him to avoid it. The conversation suggests that Wladimir was planning to undertake an action related to language import, but the consequences of such an action were not clear. Pavel's warning indicates that the import could have adverse effects on some aspects, which is why he suggested Wladimir to avoid it.
